awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Testing the drivers and scale-dependency of plant-fungal-bacterial community co-assembly across the Arctic
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposed Award Abstract

Arctic vegetation is rapidly changing in response to broad-scale Arctic warming.  The investigators of this proposal argue that only by exploring how plants, soil microbes, and soil fungal communities interact and evolve together can we truly understand how vegetation may change in the future.  Using over 3500 soil samples that have been collected across the arctic, along with environmental and plant data at the same sites, the investigators will employ new genetic and statistical techniques to understand the complex plant-microbe-fungal relations.  While the work tackles a number of basic ecological questions, it will also provide insights into the controls determining how vegetation may change in the near future.

The University of New Mexico is a certified Hispanic Serving Institution and of the 1600 undergraduate Biology majors, over 30% are Hispanic.  Taylor and Takacs-Vesbach will provide project related research experience to these and other under-represented students.  Taylor and Takacs-Vesbach are currently mentor students through three STEM programs based in the Biology department.  A letter of support is provided by the Director of the UNM Minority Access to Research Careers (MARC) Program, which commits him to helping the program recruit MARC Program Scholars for training in microbiome methods. The proposal includes for the training of a female post-doctoral scientist at the University of Alaska, Fairbanks.

The investigators pose a series of hypotheses that focus on the ecological drivers of community assembly (dispersal, environmental filtering, competition, facilitation, niche partitioning, neutral processes) across five Arctic biomes.   They will use over 3500 soil samples that have been collected along two latitudinal transects, each of which includes all five Arctic bioclimatic subzones and spans 1700 kilometers north to south.  Using their extensive sampling and next-generation-sequencing-derived data on community composition of soil fungi and bacteria that are already in hand, combined with data on plant communities at the same sites (which will be augmented with limited sequencing of plant phylogenetic markers), the investigators seek to examine the fundamental patterns of community assembly in each of the three Kingdoms at hierarchical spatial and ecological scales.

por.por_cntn:
Despite considerable attention to biodiversity patterns in the face of global change, it remains unknown whether the same ecological drivers shape patterns of diversity in prokaryotes versus eukaryotes and in microscopic, small and large organisms. Plants (large, eukaryotic), fungi (small, eukaryotic) and bacteria (microscopic, prokaryotic) interact intensively belowground and can reciprocally affect each other. Their combined interactions and activities comprise the nexus of ecosystem function in terrestrial biomes. Discovering the fundamental ecological drivers of plant-fungal-bacterial (PFB) co-assembly is particularly critical in the Arctic due to the rapid warming, ongoing shifts in vegetation, and consequences for climate feedbacks. 

We conducted the first-ever analysis of PFB co-assembly using over 3500 soil samples collected along two latitudinal transects, each of which included all five bioclimatic subzones and spanned 1700 km North to South. Our novel approach included Illumina sequencing to deeply characterize diversity of bacterial and fungal communities and exhaustive site surveys of plants and lichens.

Our results show that across and along the two Arctic transects, PFB communities are significantly structured by location (transect), subzones and a complex of abiotic filters. Climate represented the strongest filter, followed by soil pH and soil texture for plants and fungi and were generally more pronounced for plant communities than for fungal communities. However, pH was most strongly related to bacterial diversity and community composition, though location and subzone determined community composition..  The assembly of PFB communities at the local scale are more affected by stochastic processes, while deterministic processes shape the communities at a regional scale from subzone to transect. Along the bioclimatic gradients, temperature showed an increasing control over community assembly from the warmer to the coldest subzones. However, in the coldest subzones pH, soil carbon related factors and volumetric soil moisture had a stronger control over plant and fungal community composition than temperatures. 

Intellectual Merit: 

To our knowledge, no prior studies have simultaneously analyzed the composition and assembly of plant, fungal and bacterial communities across diverse habitats and a range of geographic scales. By way of an unprecedented Arctic sampling and sequencing effort, we provide novel insight into how the co-assembly of PFB communities may influence future vegetation change in the Arctic, and we advance ecological theory by revealing which ecological mechanisms dominate assembly across the three kingdoms and the extent to which cross-kingdom interactions influence assembly. 

Broader Impacts: 

This project trained a female postdoctoral researcher and a female undergraduate student and resulted in three publications and an undergraduate Honors thesis (summa cum laude in Biology).  All data generated by the project were submitted to the Arctic Data Center. As part of our public outreach, we carved an ice sculpture "Microcosm" (3.5*3*2.5 meters) at the Ice Art World Championship in Fairbanks. The sculpture depicted fungal and bacterial communities in Arctic soils and was accompanied by a poster which answered a series of questions about soil microbes in the Arctic. This event was visited by approximately 45,000 people.
